The film suffers from a certain inevitability, boosted, however, by Diane Lane's performance, which is exceptional by any standards.
If you're willing to have fun with it, you won't feel cheated by the high infidelity of Unfaithful.
Several uninteresting, unlikeable people do bad things to and with each other in ‚ÄúUnfaithful.‚Äù Why anyone who is not a character in this movie should care is beyond me.
Impeccably filmed, sexually charged, but ultimately lacking in substance, not to mention dragged down by a leaden closing act.
As in Belle de Jour, sexuality both liberates and imprisons its characters, and the supposedly unconditional love between a husband and wife is tested to the limit.
More mature than Fatal Attraction, more complete than Indecent Proposal and more relevant than 9 ¬Ω Weeks, Unfaithful is at once intimate and universal cinema.
Richard Gere and Diane Lane put in fine performances as does French actor Oliver Martinez.

Slick, steamy smut served up in a series of scenes framed
like Rembrandt paintings, with a soupcon of phony
meaningfulness on the side.
'Unfaithful' cheats on itself and retreats to comfortable territory. Too bad.
Part drama, part thriller, Unfaithful is better than you might imagine. There are many subtle details and intriguing metaphors to Lyne's film that will engage the more faithful viewer.

Diane Lane, who in real-life is married to a Frenchman, gives an ecstatic performance, as her features glow with 
passion during sex.
A surprisingly intriguing film that continues Lyne's reign of the `sexy thriller' genre.
Has none of the crackle of Fatal Attraction, 9 ¬Ω Weeks, or even Indecent Proposal, and feels more like Lyne's stolid remake of Lolita.
Lyne's latest, the erotic thriller Unfaithful, further demonstrates just how far his storytelling skills have eroded.
Finds a way to tell a simple story, perhaps the simplest story of all, in a way that seems compelling and even original.
As steamy as last week's pork dumplings.
If you've ever wondered what an ending without the input of studio executives or test audiences would look like, here it is.
Here, Adrian Lyne comes as close to profundity as he is likely to get.
Quiet, adult and just about more stately than any contemporary movie this year a true study, a film with a questioning heart and mind that isn‚Äôt afraid to admit it doesn‚Äôt have all the answers.
Graphic sex may be what's attracting audiences to Unfaithful, but gripping performances by Lane and Gere are what will keep them awake.

A morose little soap opera about three vapid, insensitive people who take turns hurting each other. It's a feature-length adaptation of one of those Can This Marriage Be Saved? columns from Ladies Home Journal
Exceptionally well acted by Diane Lane and Richard Gere.
You have once again entered the bizarre realm where director Adrian Lyne holds sway, where all relationships are simultaneously broadly metaphorical, oddly abstract, and excruciatingly literal.
Diane Lane shines in Unfaithful. Almost everything else is wan.
The vintage is pure '87, with a halfhearted twist on its cautionary message: Fatal Attraction = don't have an affair with a nutjob; Unfaithful = don't if you're married to one.
Though it is difficult to take Unfaithful as seriously as it takes itself, on its own terms it's quite well done.
This seductive tease of a thriller gets the job done. It's a scorcher.
Diane Lane's sophisticated performance can't rescue Adrian Lyne's Unfaithful from its sleazy moralizing.
The audience when I saw this one was chuckling at all the wrong times, and that's a bad sign when they're supposed to be having a collective heart attack.
Diane Lane works nothing short of a minor miracle in Unfaithful.
Escapism in its purest form.
The uncommonly good screenplay by Alvin Sargent and William Broyles Jr., keeps you undecided, even tormented, about whom to empathize with and why.
Diane Lane is magnificent in this movie.
Infidelity drama is nicely shot, well-edited  and features a standout performance by Diane Lane.
While the subject matter is serious, Waking Up In Reno is played (mostly) for laughs, and there are plenty of them.
Put it somewhere between Sling Blade and South of Heaven, West of Hell in the pantheon of Billy Bob's body of work.
Cruel and inhuman cinematic punishment simultaneously degrades its characters, its stars and its audience.
I can't begin to tell you how tedious, how resolutely unamusing, how thoroughly unrewarding all of this is, and what a reckless squandering of four fine acting talents
It's about issues most adults have to face in marriage and I think that's what I liked about it -- the real issues tucked between the silly and crude storyline.
There's nothing remotely topical or sexy here.
Inconsequential road-and-buddy pic.

It would be disingenuous to call Reno a great film, but you can say that about most of the flicks moving in and out of the multiplex. This is a movie that is what it is: a pleasant distraction, a Friday night diversion, an excuse to eat popcorn.
4 friends, 2 couples, 2000 miles, and all the Pabst Blue Ribbon beer they can drink - it's the ultimate redneck road-trip.
The whole damn thing is ripe for the Jerry Springer crowd. It's all pretty cynical and condescending, too.
Stupid, infantile, redundant, sloppy, over-the-top, and amateurish. Yep, it's Waking up in Reno. Go back to sleep.
A strong contender for this year's Razzie sweep.
Everyone's to blame here.

Reno may have a few grating gaps in logic and feels as if a good chunk of its story ended up on the cutting room floor, but there is just enough charm and humor peppered throughout to make it feel as if it wasn't a complete waste of time to sit through.
A few zingers aside, the writing is indifferent, and Jordan Brady's direction is prosaic.
An extremely unpleasant film.

It won't harm anyone, but neither can I think of a very good reason to rush right out and see it. After all, it'll probably be in video stores by Christmas, and it might just be better suited to a night in the living room than a night at the movies.
It‚Äôs a movie that ends with Truckzilla, for cryin‚Äô out loud. If that doesn‚Äôt clue you in that something‚Äôs horribly wrong, nothing will.
built on the premise that middle-class Arkansas consists of monster truck-loving good ol' boys and peroxide blond honeys whose worldly knowledge comes from TV reruns and supermarket tabloids.
This movie is about lying, cheating, but loving the friends you betray.
Brady achieves the remarkable feat of squandering a topnotch foursome of actors  by shoving them into every clich√©d white-trash situation imaginable.
Oozes condescension from every pore.
Offers big, fat, dumb laughs that may make you hate yourself for giving in. Ah, what the hell.
Every note rings false.
I like all four of the lead actors a lot and they manage to squeeze a few laughs out of the material, but they're treading water at best in this forgettable effort.
Finally coming down off of Miramax's deep shelves after a couple of aborted attempts, Waking Up in Reno makes a strong case for letting sleeping dogs lie.
Nothing in Waking Up in Reno ever inspired me to think of its inhabitants as anything more than markers in a screenplay.
A feature-length, R-rated, road-trip version of Mama's Family.
A hillbilly romantic comedy in which the hillbillies show up but the romance and comedy never do.
Wallace directs with such patronising reverence, it turns the stomach.
a story we haven't seen on the big screen before, and it's a story that we as Americans, and human beings, should know.
Perhaps a better celebration of these unfairly dismissed heroes would be a film that isn‚Äôt this painfully forced, false and fabricated.
Wallace seems less like he's been burning to tell a war story than he's been itching to somehow tack one together
an incredibly heavy-handed, manipulative dud that feels all too familiar.
a good, if not entirely fresh, look at war.
Had I suffered and bled on the hard ground of Ia Drang, I'd want something a bit more complex than We Were Soldiers to be remembered by.

Crisply and efficiently madebut ultimately its very old-fashioned
earnestness makes it seem a little creaky,like a cinematic
nostalgia trip.
Supposedly authentic account of a historical event that's far too tragic to merit such superficial treatment.
Offers no new insight on the matter, nor do its characters exactly spring to life.
Wallace gets a bit heavy handed with his message at times, and has a visual flair that waxes poetic far too much for our taste.
Fails to bring as much to the table.
The film feels formulaic, its plot and pacing typical Hollywood war-movie stuff, while the performances elicit more of a sense of deja vu than awe.
A must-see for fans of thoughtful war films and those interested in the sights and sounds of battle.

While some will object to the idea of a Vietnam picture with such a rah-rah, patriotic tone, Soldiers ultimately achieves its main strategic objective: dramatizing the human cost of the conflict that came to define a generation.
Writer-director Randall Wallace has bitten off more than he or anyone else could chew, and his movie veers like a drunken driver through heavy traffic.
Wallace is smart to vary the pitch of his movie, balancing deafening battle scenes with quieter domestic scenes of women back home receiving War Department telegrams.
With We Were Soldiers, Hollywood makes a valiant attempt to tell a story about the Vietnam War before the pathology set in.
I‚Äôve said it before and I‚Äôll say it again: Just because it‚Äôs a true story, that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs a great one.
Even the presence of a Hollywood megastar like Mel Gibson doesn‚Äôt detract from the vividly authentic look and feel of the battle scenes.

This is a soldier's action-war film, that eulogizes them as noble heroes in a questionable war that has turned into a 
nightmare.
plays like an unbalanced mixture of graphic combat footage and almost saccharine domestic interludes that are pure Hollywood.
The only thing that distinguishes a Randall Wallace film from any other is the fact that there is nothing distinguishing in a Randall Wallace film.
Mel Gibson fights the good fight in Vietnam in director Randall Wallace's flag-waving war flick with a core of decency.
The film succeeds as an homage to human spirit in the most shattering of circumstances.
It's unfortunate that Wallace, who wrote Gibson's Braveheart as well as the recent Pearl Harbor, has such an irrepressible passion for sappy situations and dialogue.
Has an impact that transcends politics and some dramatic overreaching by writer-director Randall Wallace.
By attributing intelligence, bravery and above all, humanity, to enemy forces as well as to U.S. troops, We Were Soldiers does itself proud.
The sentimental cliches mar an otherwise excellent film. A powerful performance from Mel Gibson and a brutal 90-minute battle sequence that does everything but issue you a dog-tag and an M-16.
At its best, it's Black Hawk Down with more heart. At its worst, it's Rambo- meets-John Ford.
Like the best war movies -- and like martial literature going back to the Iliad -- it balances the dreadful, unassuageable cruelty of warfare and the valor and decency of those who fight.

The writer-director bestows honor -- generously, apolitically -- not only on the dead and still living American veterans who fought in Ia Drang, but also on their families, on their Vietnamese adversaries, and on the families of their adversaries too.
As I settled into my World War II memories, I found myself strangely moved by even the corniest and most hackneyed contrivances.
Another in a long line of ultra-violent war movies, this one is not quite what it could have been as a film, but the story and theme make up for it.
Feels slight, as if it were an extended short, albeit one made by the smartest kids in class.

It's excessively quirky and a little underconfident in its delivery, but otherwise this is the best 'old neighborhood' project since Christopher Walken kinda romanced Cyndi Lauper in The Opportunists.
While locals will get a kick out of spotting Cleveland sites, the rest of the world will enjoy a fast-paced comedy with quirks that might make the award-winning Coen brothers envious.
Despite some comic sparks, Welcome to Collinwood never catches fire.
Criminal conspiracies and true romances move so easily across racial and cultural lines in the film that it makes My Big Fat Greek Wedding look like an apartheid drama.
A zippy, enormously entertaining heist movie that, with a kind heart at its core, encompasses the styles of yesterday, today, and if we're lucky, maybe even tomorrow.
Enjoyably dumb, sweet, and intermittently hilarious -- if you've a taste for the quirky, steal a glimpse.
It doesn't quite work, but there's enough here to make us look forward to the Russos' next offering.
Just a bunch of good actors flailing around in a caper that's neither original nor terribly funny.
After all the big build-up, the payoff for the audience, as well as the characters, is messy, murky, unsatisfying.
Like these Russo guys lookin‚Äô for their Mamet instead found their Sturges.
The off-center humor is a constant, and the ensemble gives it a buoyant delivery.
A warm and hugely enjoyable romp.
Has a shambling charma cheerfully inconsequential diversion.
The gags that fly at such a furiously funny pace that the only rip off that we were aware of was the one we felt when the movie ended so damned soon.
The kind of film that leaves you scratching your head in amazement over the fact that so many talented people could participate in such an ill-advised and poorly executed idea.

This goofy gangster yarn never really elevates itself from being yet another earnestly generic crime-busting comic vehicle --  a well-intentioned remake that shows some spunk and promise but fails to register as anything distinctive or daring
It's not exactly worth the bucks to expend the full price for a date, but when it comes out on video, it's well worth a rental.
You could easily mistake it for a sketchy work-in-progress that was inexplicably rushed to the megaplexes before its time.
Light, cute and forgettable.
It's often faintly amusing, but the problems of the characters never become important to us, and the story never takes hold.
Droll caper-comedy remake of Big Deal on Madonna Street that's a sly, amusing, laugh-filled little gem in which the ultimate Bellini begins to look like a real Kaputschnik.
You can tell almost immediately that Welcome to Collinwood isn't going to jell.
The entire point of a shaggy dog story, of course, is that it goes nowhere, and this is classic nowheresville in every sense.
It's supposed to be a humorous, all-too-human look at how hope can breed a certain kind of madness -- and strength -- but it never quite adds up.
The whole cast looks to be having so much fun with the slapstick antics and silly street patois, tossing around obscure expressions like Bellini and Mullinski, that the compact 86 minutes breezes by.
A few hours after you've seen it, you forget you've been to the movies.
The picture runs a mere 84 minutes, but it's no glance. It's a head-turner -- thoughtfully written, beautifully read and, finally, deeply humanizing.
Can't kick about the assembled talent and the Russos show genuine promise as comic filmmakers. Still, this thing feels flimsy and ephemeral.
An enjoyably half-wit remake of the venerable Italian comedy Big Deal on Madonna Street.

The doofus-on- the-loose banter of Welcome to Collinwood has a cocky, after-hours loopiness to it. And as with most late-night bull sessions, eventually the content isn't nearly as captivating as the rowdy participants think it is.
Yet another self-consciously overwritten story about a rag-tag bunch of would-be characters that team up for a can‚Äôt-miss heist -- only to have it all go wrong.
Kept aloft largely by a comically adept ensemble.
Sometimes this modest little number clicks, and sometimes it doesn't.
This one is a few bits funnier than Malle's dud, if only because the cast is so engagingly messing around like Slob City reductions of Damon Runyon crooks.
How this one escaped the Lifetime network I'll never know.
A marvelous performance by Allison Lohman as an identity-seeking foster child.

The leaping story line, shaped by director Peter Kosminsky into sharp slivers and cutting impressions, shows all the signs of rich detail condensed into a few evocative images and striking character traits.
'Synthetic' is the best description of this well-meaning, beautifully produced film that sacrifices its promise for a high-powered star pedigree.
But this is Lohman‚Äôs film. Her performance moves between heartbreak and rebellion as she continually tries to accommodate to fit in and gain the unconditional love she seeks.
Engrossing and affecting, if ultimately not quite satisfying.
To those who have not read the book, the film is a much better mother-daughter tale than last summer's 'Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood,' but that's not saying much.

A compelling coming-of-age drama about the arduous journey of a sensitive young girl through a series of  foster homes and a  fierce struggle to pull free from her dangerous and domineering mother's hold over her.
Moved me and blew me away with the incredible acting by all and left me with the desire to read the book to hopefully find out more about these characters.
Lohman adapts to the changes required of her, but the actress and director Peter Kosminsky never get the audience to break through the wall her character erects
No amount of good acting is enough to save Oleander‚Äôs uninspired story.
The performances of the four main actresses bring their characters to life. A little melodramatic, but with enough hope to keep you engaged.
Kosminsky  puts enough salt into the wounds of the tortured and self-conscious material to make it sting.
(A) Hollywood sheen bedevils the film from the very beginning(but) Lohman's moist, deeply emotional eyes shine through this bogus veneer
The cast is phenomenal, especially the women.
White Oleander may leave you rolling your eyes in the dark, but that doesn't mean you won't like looking at it.
If the screen version of White Oleander was an Olympic event, it's hard to tell which of the movie's four actresses would end up winning the gold.
A broad, melodramatic estrogen opera that's pretty toxic in its own right.
‚ÄúWhite Oleander,‚Äù the movie, is akin to a Reader‚Äôs Digest condensed version of the source material.
A women's movie, not a chick flick.
It's got some pretentious eye-rolling moments and it didn't entirely grab me, but there's stuff here to like.
Nothing but one relentlessly depressing situation after another for its entire running time, something that you could easily be dealing with right now in your lives.
The cast delivers without sham the raw-nerved story.
What could have been a daytime soap opera is actually a compelling look at a young woman's tragic odyssey.
For what it is, Kosminsky's picture is polished and effective. If only the movie had taken more risks or possessed a keener edge
This is a third-person story now, told by Hollywood, and much more ordinary for it.
The film takes the materials of human tragedy and dresses them in lovely costumes, Southern California locations and star power.
A smart, compelling drama.
Call me a cynic, but there's something awfully deadly about any movie with a life-affirming message.
They kept much of the plot but jettisoned the stuff that would make this a moving experience for people who haven't read the book.
Superbly acted from top to bottom.
In the end, White Oleander isn't an adaptation of a novel. It's a flashy, star-splashed reduction.
Though it flirts with bathos and pathos and the further Oprahfication of the world as we know it, it still cuts all the way down to broken bone.
Never rising above routine episodic storytelling, White Oleander nonetheless retains something of its source novel's ravaged emotional surface and cool, observant manner.
Director Peter Kosminsky gives these women a forum to demonstrate their acting 'chops' and they take full advantage.
This is the first full scale WWII flick from Hong Kong's John Woo. He's not good with people.
When it comes to the battle of Hollywood vs. Woo, it looks like Woo's a P.O.W.
What ultimately makes Windtalkers a disappointment is the superficial way it deals with its story.

Woo has as much right to make a huge action sequence as any director, but how long will filmmakers copy the ‚ÄúSaving Private Ryan‚Äù battle scenes before realizing Steven Spielberg got it right the first time?
Woo's fights have a distinct flair. His warriors collide in balletic explosion that implies an underlying order throughout the chaos.
The directive to protect the code at all costs also begins to blur as the importance of the man and the code merge
A man leaving the screening said the film was better than Saving Private Ryan. He may have meant the Internet short Saving Ryan's Privates. But Windtalkers doesn't beat that one, either.
Woo's most resonant film since The Killer.
With its dogged Hollywood naturalism and the inexorable passage of its characters toward sainthood, Windtalkers is nothing but a sticky-sweet soap.
Isn't quite the equal of Woo's best earlier work, but it's easily his finest American filmcomes close to recapturing the brilliance of his Hong Kong films.

This is a great subject for a movie, but Hollywood has squandered the opportunity, using it as a prop for warmed-over melodrama and the kind of choreographed mayhem that director John Woo has built his career on.
Strip it of all its excess debris, and you'd have a 90-minute, four-star movie. As it is, it's too long and unfocused.
An uninspired preachy and clich√©d war film.
That the Chuck Norris grenade gag occurs about 7 times during Windtalkers is a good indication of how serious-minded the film is.
The major problem with Windtalkers is that the bulk of the movie centers on the wrong character.
An appealing and well-acted film.
Unfortunately, contrived plotting, stereotyped characters and Woo's over-the-top instincts as a director undermine the moral dilemma at the movie's heart.
Done in mostly by a weak script that can't support the epic treatment.

Some of the most ravaging, gut-wrenching, frightening war scenes since Saving Private Ryan have been recreated by John Woo in this little-known story of Native Americans and their role in the second great war.
Windtalkers celebrates the human spirit and packs an emotional wallop.
if you, like me, think an action film disguised as a war tribute is disgusting to begin with, then you're in for a painful ride.
In the wake of Saving Private Ryan, Black Hawk Down and We Were Soldiers, you are likely to be as heartily sick of mayhem as Cage's war-weary marine.
It's mired in a shabby script that piles layer upon layer of Action Man clich√© atop wooden dialogue and a shifting tone that falls far short of the peculiarly moral amorality of Woo's best work.
I kept wishing I was watching a documentary about the wartime Navajos and what they accomplished instead of all this specious Hollywood hoo-ha.
Windtalkers is shapelessly gratifying, the kind of movie that invites you to pick apart its faults even as you have to admit that somehow it hit you where you live.
The screenplay sabotages the movie's strengths at almost every juncture. All the characters are stereotypes, and their interaction is numbingly predictable.
Throwing in everything except someone pulling the pin from a grenade with his teeth, Windtalkers seems to have ransacked every old World War II movie for overly familiar material.
The code talkers deserved better than a hollow tribute.
No amount of burning, blasting, stabbing, and shooting can hide a weak script.
The history is fascinating; the action is dazzling. They just don't work in concert.

Directed without the expected flair or imagination by Hong Kong master John Woo, Windtalkers airs just about every cliche in the war movie compendium across its indulgent two-hour-and-fifteen-minute length.
Windtalkers blows this way and that, but there's no mistaking the filmmaker in the tall grass, true to himself.

I wish Windtalkers had had more faith in the dramatic potential of this true story. This would have been better than the fiction it has concocted, and there still could have been room for the war scenes.
A relentless, bombastic and ultimately empty World War II action flick.
Disappointing in comparison to other recent war movies‚Ä¶or any other John Woo flick for that matter.
Triple X is a double agent, and he's one bad dude. When you‚Äôve got the wildly popular Vin Diesel in the equation, it adds up to big box office bucks all but guaranteed.
All the amped-up Tony Hawk-style stunts and thrashing rap-metal can't disguise the fact that, really, we've been here, done that.
A mediocre exercise in target demographics, unaware that it's the butt of its own joke.
For all its posturing, XXX essentially is a James Bond movie refitted for the Tony Hawk crowd.
Bond-inspired? Certainly. Likely to have decades of life as a classic movie franchise? Let‚Äôs hope not.
Don't walk into the theater expecting anything other than fist-pumping action.
although this idea is new the results are tired.
The AAA of action, XXX is a blast of adrenalin, rated EEE for excitement. And Vin Diesel is the man.
If you like an extreme action-packed film with a hint of humor, then Triple X marks the spot.
Despite its detriments, xXx is entertaining -- mostly for one reason: Diesel.
It's a boom-box of a movie that might have been titled 'The Loud and the Ludicrous'the pandering to a moviegoing audience dominated by young males is all too calculated.
‚ÄúXXX‚Äù so often gets the fun of the superhero genre exactly right that its faults are that much more tragic. It could have been so much more than it is.
It‚Äôs dumb fun slapped silly, a new franchise inspired by the Bond films that‚Äôs not far from the porn its title promises; the film is a veritable orgy of outrageous stunts.
Call me a cold-hearted curmudgeon for not being able to enjoy a mindless action movie, but I believe a movie can be mindless without being the peak of all things insipid.
None of this has the suavity or classical familiarity of Bond, but much of it is good for a laugh. The problem with XXX is that its own action isn't very effective.
This would-be 'James Bond for the Extreme Generation' pic is one big, dumb action movie. Stress 'dumb.'
Never mind that it's often  crude, gauche, and obnoxious. It never pretends to be otherwise, and in its flagrant honesty, it earns a strange sort of respect.
xXx re-engineers Bond for a savvier, more cynical generation.
Can I admit XXX is as deep as a Petri dish and as well-characterized as a telephone book but still say it was a guilty pleasure?
Let's face it, even Vin's fake tats have more charisma than Pierce Brosnan.
Is the time really ripe for a warmed-over James Bond adventure, with a village idiot as the 007 clone?
You can watch, giggle and get an adrenaline boost without feeling like you've completely lowered your entertainment standards.
Soulless and -- even more damning -- virtually joyless, XXX achieves near virtuosity in its crapulence.
Despite its raucous intent, XXX is as conventional as a Nike ad and as rebellious as spring break.
In XXX, Diesel is that rare creature -- an action hero with table manners, and one who proves that elegance is more than tattoo deep.
For all its alleged youthful fire, XXX is no less subservient to Bond's tired formula of guns, girls and gadgets while brandishing a new action hero.
More busy than exciting, more frantic than involving, more chaotic than entertaining.
Cohen  loads the film with pow.
Every defiantly over-the-top action scene -- from high-stakes car chases to fearsome drug busts -- seizes your adrenal gland and milks it like an epileptic farmer.
It's hard to tell with all the crashing and banging where the salesmanship ends and the movie begins.
Even in the summertime, the most restless young audience deserves the dignity of an action hero motivated by something more than franchise possibilities.
The pretensions -- and disposable story -- sink the movie. And Diesel isn't the actor to save it.
Unrelentingly stupid.
It's got the brawn, but not the brains.
It's refreshing that someone understands the need for the bad boy; Diesel, with his brawny frame and cool, composed delivery, fits the bill perfectly.
